ai-ud3.3:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-ud3.3:1.3_0: Now at that time around five hundred mendicants headed by Yasoja arrived at Sāvatthī to see the Buddha.
ai-ud3.3:1.4_0: At that, those visiting mendicants, while exchanging pleasantries with the resident mendicants, preparing their lodgings, and putting away their bowls and robes, made a dreadful racket.
ai-ud3.3:2.1_0: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Ānanda,
ai-ud3.3:2.2_0: “Ānanda, who’s making that dreadful racket? You’d think it was fishermen hauling in a catch!”
ai-ud3.3:2.3_0: “Sir, those five hundred mendicants headed by Yasoja have arrived at Sāvatthī to see the Buddha.
ai-ud3.3:2.4_0: It’s those visiting mendicants who, while exchanging pleasantries with the resident mendicants, preparing their lodgings, and putting away their bowls and robes, made a dreadful racket.”
ai-ud3.3:2.5_0: “Now then, Ānanda, with my word address those monks, (saying):
ai-ud3.3:3.1_0: “Yes, Sir.” He replied, and did as he was asked.
ai-ud3.3:3.1_1: and after going, he said this to those monks:
ai-ud3.3:3.3_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
ai-ud3.3:3.4_0: They went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to them,
ai-ud3.3:4.1_0: “Mendicants, what’s with that dreadful racket? You’d think it was fishermen hauling in a catch!”
ai-ud3.3:4.2_0: After that was said, venerable Yasoja said this to the Fortunate One:
ai-ud3.3:4.3_0: “Sir, these five hundred mendicants headed by Yasoja have arrived at Sāvatthī to see the Buddha.
ai-ud3.3:4.4_0: It’s these visiting mendicants who, while exchanging pleasantries with the resident mendicants, preparing their lodgings, and putting away their bowls and robes, made a dreadful racket.”
ai-ud3.3:4.5_0: “Go away, mendicants, I dismiss you. You are not to stay in my presence.”
ai-ud3.3:4.6_0: You should not live in my presence.”
ai-ud3.3:5.1_0: “Yes, sir,” replied those mendicants. They got up from their seats, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right. They set their lodgings in order and left, taking their bowls and robes.
ai-ud3.3:5.2_0: Traveling stage by stage in the land of the Vajjīs, they arrived at the Vaggumudā.
ai-ud3.3:5.2_1: and after going and making leaf-huts on the bank of the river Vaggumudā they spent the rainy season.
ai-ud3.3:6.1_0: Then Venerable Yasoja, having entered the rainy season, addressed the mendicants:
ai-ud3.3:6.2_0: “Out of compassion, reverends, the Buddha dismissed us, wanting what’s best for us.
ai-ud3.3:6.3_0: Come, let us live in such a way that the Buddha would be pleased with us.”
ai-ud3.3:6.5_0: Then those mendicants, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, all realized the three knowledges in that same rainy season.
ai-ud3.3:7.1_0: After staying in Sāvatthī for as long as he liked, the Buddha set out wandering toward Vesālī.
ai-ud3.3:7.3_0: he stayed in the hall with the peaked roof in the Great Wood.
ai-ud3.3:8.1_0: Then the Buddha, knowing what that they had done, addressed Venerable Ānanda,
ai-ud3.3:8.2_0: “A light, it appears to me, has arisen in this quarter, Ānanda; a brightness has arisen.
ai-ud3.3:8.3_0: I’m not put off at the thought of going to where the mendicants are staying on the bank of the river Vaggumudā.
ai-ud3.3:8.4_0: and to apply my mind is not disagreeable.
ai-ud3.3:8.5_0: Send a message to those mendicants:
ai-ud3.3:9.1_1: and after going, he said this to that monk:
ai-ud3.3:9.2_0: “Come, venerable friend, you should go to the monks on the bank of the Vaggumudā,
ai-ud3.3:9.2_1: and after going, please say this to the monks on the bank of the Vaggumudā:
ai-ud3.3:10.2_0: Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, they vanished from the bank of the river Vaggumudā, and reappeared in the presence of the Buddha in the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
ai-ud3.3:10.4_0: and reappear in front of those monks on the bank of the river Vaggumudā.
ai-ud3.3:10.5_0: Then that monk said this to the monks on the bank of the Vaggumudā:
ai-ud3.3:10.6_0: “Venerables, the teacher summons you. He wants to see you.”
ai-ud3.3:11.1_0: “Yes, reverend,” replied those mendicants. They set their lodgings in order and took their bowls and robes.
ai-ud3.3:11.2_0: Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, they vanished from the bank of the river Vaggumudā, and reappeared in the presence of the Buddha in the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
ai-ud3.3:11.4_0: and reappear in front of the Buddha.
ai-ud3.3:11.5_0: Then at that time the Fortunate One was sitting in imperturbable concentration.
ai-ud3.3:11.7_0: “What kind of meditation is the Buddha practicing right now?”
ai-ud3.3:11.10_0: They all sat in imperturbable meditation.
ai-ud3.3:12.1_0: Then, when the night was well advanced and the first part of the night was over, Venerable Ānanda got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha and said,
ai-ud3.3:12.2_0: “Sir, the night is getting late. It is the first watch of the night, and the visiting mendicants have been sitting long.
ai-ud3.3:12.3_0: if he leaves out the first watch,
ai-ud3.3:12.4_0: for a long time (these) visiting monks have been sitting,
ai-ud3.3:12.5_0: Sir, please greet the visiting mendicants.”
ai-ud3.3:12.6_0: When this was said, the Fortunate One remained silent.
ai-ud3.3:13.1_0: For a second time, as the night was getting late, in the middle watch of the night, Ānanda got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha and said,
ai-ud3.3:13.2_0: “Sir, the night is getting late. It is the first watch of the night, and the visiting mendicants have been sitting long.
ai-ud3.3:13.3_0: the middle watch of the night has gone out.
ai-ud3.3:13.4_0: for a long time (these) visiting monks have been sitting,
ai-ud3.3:13.5_0: Sir, please greet the visiting mendicants.”
ai-ud3.3:13.6_0: But for a second time the Buddha kept silent.
ai-ud3.3:14.1_0: For a third time, as the night was getting late, in the last watch of the night, Ānanda got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha and said,
ai-ud3.3:14.2_0: “Sir, the night is getting late. It is the first watch of the night, and the visiting mendicants have been sitting long.
ai-ud3.3:14.3_0: Since he came out, the last watch of the night has gone out,
ai-ud3.3:14.6_0: for a long time (these) visiting monks have been sitting,
ai-ud3.3:14.7_0: Sir, please greet the visiting mendicants.”
ai-ud3.3:15.1_0: Then the Buddha emerged from that immersion and addressed Ānanda,
ai-ud3.3:15.2_0: “If you knew, Ānanda, you would not say even this much about them.
ai-ud3.3:15.3_0: Both I and these five hundred mendicants have been sitting in imperturbable meditation.”
ai-ud3.3:16.1_0: Then, knowing the significance of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ai-ud3.3:17.1_0: “A mendicant who has beaten the thorns of sensuality—
ai-ud3.3:17.4_0: trembles not at pleasure and pain.”
